segment.source: BCD System Store Settings for UEFI
segment.target: BCD System Store Settings for UEFI

segment.source: BCD System Store Settings for UEFI
segment.target: BCD System Store Settings for UEFI

segment.source: BCD System Store Settings for UEFI
segment.target: BCD System Store Settings for UEFI

segment.source: For a typical deployment scenario, you do not need to modify the BCD store.
segment.target: For a typical deployment scenario, you do not need to modify the BCD store.

segment.source: This topic discusses the various BCD settings in the BCD store that you can modify.
segment.target: This topic discusses the various BCD settings in the BCD store that you can modify.

segment.source: On UEFI systems, this includes settings for the following boot applications:
segment.target: On UEFI systems, this includes settings for the following boot applications:

segment.source: Windows Boot Manager
segment.target: Windows Boot Manager

segment.source: Windows Boot Loader
segment.target: Windows Boot Loader

segment.source: Windows Memory Tester
segment.target: Windows Memory Tester

segment.source: The following sections describe the available settings for each of these boot applications in detail and how to modify each application for UEFI systems.
segment.target: The following sections describe the available settings for each of these boot applications in detail and how to modify each application for UEFI systems.

segment.source: For simplicity, the BCDEdit examples in this section modify the BCD system store.
segment.target: For simplicity, the BCDEdit examples in this section modify the BCD system store.

segment.source: To modify another store, such as a copy of the BCD-template, include the store name in the command line.
segment.target: To modify another store, such as a copy of the BCD-template, include the store name in the command line.

segment.source: Windows Boot Manager Settings for UEFI
segment.target: Windows Boot Manager Settings for UEFI

segment.source: Windows Boot Manager () manages the boot process.
segment.target: Windows Boot Manager () manages the boot process.

segment.source: UEFI-based systems contain a firmware boot manager, Bootmgfw.efi, that loads an EFI application that is based on variables that are stored in NVRAM.
segment.target: UEFI-based systems contain a firmware boot manager, Bootmgfw.efi, that loads an EFI application that is based on variables that are stored in NVRAM.

segment.source: The BCD settings for the and elements in Windows Boot Manager indicate the firmware boot manager.
segment.target: The BCD settings for the and elements in Windows Boot Manager indicate the firmware boot manager.

segment.source: The template that is named BCD-template for Windows includes the following settings for Windows Boot Manager.
segment.target: The template that is named BCD-template for Windows includes the following settings for Windows Boot Manager.

segment.source: Device Setting
segment.target: Device Setting

segment.source: The element specifies the volume that contains Windows Boot Manager.
segment.target: The element specifies the volume that contains Windows Boot Manager.

segment.source: For UEFI systems, the element for Windows Boot Manager is set to the system partition volume letter.
segment.target: For UEFI systems, the element for Windows Boot Manager is set to the system partition volume letter.

segment.source: To determine the correct volume letter, use the Diskpart tool to view the disk partitions.
segment.target: To determine the correct volume letter, use the Diskpart tool to view the disk partitions.

segment.source: The following example assumes that the system has a single hard drive that has multiple partitions, including a system partition that has been assigned a drive letter of S.
segment.target: The following example assumes that the system has a single hard drive that has multiple partitions, including a system partition that has been assigned a drive letter of S.

segment.source: The following Diskpart commands select disk 0 and then list the details of the volumes on that disk, including their drive letters.
segment.target: The following Diskpart commands select disk 0 and then list the details of the volumes on that disk, including their drive letters.

segment.source: It shows volume 2 as the system partition.
segment.target: It shows volume 2 as the system partition.

segment.source: If the system partition does not have an assigned drive letter, assign one by using the Diskpart assign command.
segment.target: If the system partition does not have an assigned drive letter, assign one by using the Diskpart assign command.

segment.source: The following example assumes that the system partition is volume 2 and assigns it S as the drive letter.
segment.target: The following example assumes that the system partition is volume 2 and assigns it S as the drive letter.

segment.source: After you have determined the system partition volume, set the element for Windows Boot Manager to the corresponding drive letter.
segment.target: After you have determined the system partition volume, set the element for Windows Boot Manager to the corresponding drive letter.

segment.source: The following example sets to drive S.
segment.target: The following example sets to drive S.

segment.source: Path Setting
segment.target: Path Setting

segment.source: The element specifies the location of the Windows Boot Manager application on that volume.
segment.target: The element specifies the location of the Windows Boot Manager application on that volume.

segment.source: For UEFI systems, indicates the firmware boot manager, whose path is EFIMicrosoftBootBootmgfw.efi.
segment.target: For UEFI systems, indicates the firmware boot manager, whose path is EFIMicrosoftBootBootmgfw.efi.

segment.source: You can confirm that BCD-template has the correct path by enumerating the values in the store, as follows:
segment.target: You can confirm that BCD-template has the correct path by enumerating the values in the store, as follows:

segment.source: To explicitly set to EFIMicrosoftBootBootmgfw.efi, use the following command.
segment.target: To explicitly set to EFIMicrosoftBootBootmgfw.efi, use the following command.

segment.source: Other Settings
segment.target: Other Settings

segment.source: You should set Windows Boot Manager to be the first item in the display order of the UEFI firmware, as shown in the following example.
segment.target: You should set Windows Boot Manager to be the first item in the display order of the UEFI firmware, as shown in the following example.

segment.source: You should also specify the topmost Windows boot loader application in the Windows Boot Manager display order.
segment.target: You should also specify the topmost Windows boot loader application in the Windows Boot Manager display order.

segment.source: The following example shows how to put a specified Windows boot loader at the top of the display order.
segment.target: The following example shows how to put a specified Windows boot loader at the top of the display order.

segment.source: In the preceding example, GUID is the identifier for the specified Windows boot loader object.
segment.target: In the preceding example, GUID is the identifier for the specified Windows boot loader object.

segment.source: The next section discusses this identifier in greater detail.
segment.target: The next section discusses this identifier in greater detail.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: A multiboot system that has multiple installed operating systems has multiple instances of the Windows boot loader.
segment.target: A multiboot system that has multiple installed operating systems has multiple instances of the Windows boot loader.

segment.source: Each instance of the Windows boot loader has its own identifier.
segment.target: Each instance of the Windows boot loader has its own identifier.

segment.source: You can set the default Windows boot loader () to any of these identifiers.
segment.target: You can set the default Windows boot loader () to any of these identifiers.

segment.source: Windows Boot Loader Settings
segment.target: Windows Boot Loader Settings

segment.source: A BCD store has at least one instance, and optionally multiple instances, of the Windows boot loader.
segment.target: A BCD store has at least one instance, and optionally multiple instances, of the Windows boot loader.

segment.source: A separate BCD object represents each instance.
segment.target: A separate BCD object represents each instance.

segment.source: Each instance loads one of the installed versions of Windows that has a configuration that the object's elements have specified.
segment.target: Each instance loads one of the installed versions of Windows that has a configuration that the object's elements have specified.

segment.source: Each Windows boot loader object has its own identifier, and the object's and settings indicate the correct partition and boot application.
segment.target: Each Windows boot loader object has its own identifier, and the object's and settings indicate the correct partition and boot application.

segment.source: for Windows has a single Windows boot loader object that has the following settings.
segment.target: for Windows has a single Windows boot loader object that has the following settings.

segment.source: The identifier for this Windows boot loader is {9f25ee7a-e7b7-11db-94b5-f7e662935912}.
segment.target: The identifier for this Windows boot loader is {9f25ee7a-e7b7-11db-94b5-f7e662935912}.

segment.source: You can use this GUID on your system or let the BCDEdit tool generate a new GUID for you.
segment.target: You can use this GUID on your system or let the BCDEdit tool generate a new GUID for you.

segment.source: To simplify BCDEdit commands, you can specify one of the Windows boot loaders in the BCD system store as the default loader.
segment.target: To simplify BCDEdit commands, you can specify one of the Windows boot loaders in the BCD system store as the default loader.

segment.source: You can then use the standard identifier () in place of the full GUID.The following example specifies the Windows boot loader for EFI as the default boot loader, assuming that it uses the identifier GUID from BCD-template.
segment.target: You can then use the standard identifier () in place of the full GUID.The following example specifies the Windows boot loader for EFI as the default boot loader, assuming that it uses the identifier GUID from BCD-template.

segment.source: Device and OSDevice Settings
segment.target: Device and OSDevice Settings

segment.source: The following elements specify key locations:
segment.target: The following elements specify key locations:

segment.source: The element specifies the partition that contains the boot application.
segment.target: The element specifies the partition that contains the boot application.

segment.source: The element specifies the partition that contains the system root.
segment.target: The element specifies the partition that contains the system root.

segment.source: For the Windows boot loader for EFI, both elements are usually set to the drive letter of the Windows system partition.
segment.target: For the Windows boot loader for EFI, both elements are usually set to the drive letter of the Windows system partition.

segment.source: However, if BitLocker is enabled or a computer has multiple installed versions of Windows, and might be set to different partitions.BCD-template sets both elements to drive C, which is the typical value.
segment.target: However, if BitLocker is enabled or a computer has multiple installed versions of Windows, and might be set to different partitions.BCD-template sets both elements to drive C, which is the typical value.

segment.source: You can also explicitly set the and values, as shown in the following example.
segment.target: You can also explicitly set the and values, as shown in the following example.

segment.source: The example also assumes that you have specified the Windows boot loader for EFI as the default boot-loader object.
segment.target: The example also assumes that you have specified the Windows boot loader for EFI as the default boot-loader object.

segment.source: Path Setting
segment.target: Path Setting

segment.source: The element of a Windows boot loader specifies the location of the boot loader on that volume.
segment.target: The element of a Windows boot loader specifies the location of the boot loader on that volume.

segment.source: For UEFI systems, indicates the Windows boot loader for EFI, whose path is WindowsSystem32Winload.efi.
segment.target: For UEFI systems, indicates the Windows boot loader for EFI, whose path is WindowsSystem32Winload.efi.

segment.source: You can confirm that BCD-template has the correct value by enumerating the values in the store.
segment.target: You can confirm that BCD-template has the correct value by enumerating the values in the store.

segment.source: You can also explicitly set the value, as shown in the following example.
segment.target: You can also explicitly set the value, as shown in the following example.

segment.source: Windows Memory Tester Settings
segment.target: Windows Memory Tester Settings

segment.source: The Windows memory tester () runs memory diagnostics at boot time.
segment.target: The Windows memory tester () runs memory diagnostics at boot time.

segment.source: The BCD settings for the application's and elements indicate the correct application.
segment.target: The BCD settings for the application's and elements indicate the correct application.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Note: Intel Itanium computers do not include a Windows memory tester and do not require settings.
segment.target: Note: Intel Itanium computers do not include a Windows memory tester and do not require settings.

segment.source: BCD-template for Windows has the following settings.
segment.target: BCD-template for Windows has the following settings.

segment.source: Device Setting
segment.target: Device Setting

segment.source: For UEFI systems, the element for the Windows memory tester is set to the system partition drive letter.
segment.target: For UEFI systems, the element for the Windows memory tester is set to the system partition drive letter.

segment.source: The following example assumes that the system partition is drive S, as used in earlier examples.
segment.target: The following example assumes that the system partition is drive S, as used in earlier examples.

segment.source: Path Setting
segment.target: Path Setting

segment.source: The element specifies the location of Windows Test Manager on the volume that the element has specified.
segment.target: The element specifies the location of Windows Test Manager on the volume that the element has specified.

segment.source: For UEFI systems, indicates the EFI version of the application (EFIMicrosoftBootMemtest.efi).
segment.target: For UEFI systems, indicates the EFI version of the application (EFIMicrosoftBootMemtest.efi).

segment.source: You can confirm that BCD-template has the correct value by enumerating the values in the store.
segment.target: You can confirm that BCD-template has the correct value by enumerating the values in the store.

segment.source: You can also use the BCDEdit tool to explicitly set the value, as shown in the following example.
segment.target: You can also use the BCDEdit tool to explicitly set the value, as shown in the following example.
